GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Dry Eye Disease
Corneal and conjunctival dryness and discomfort caused by decreased tear secretion or stability, common in overuse of eyes or tear film abnormalities.
Retinal Detachment
Separation of the photosensitive cell layer from the pigment epithelium due to retinal tears or traction, often presenting as flashes, floaters, and a curtain-like shadow.
Anterior Uveitis

Predominantly inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, presenting with ciliary congestion, photophobia, eye pain, and decreased vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals anterior chamber cells and flare.
Cataract
Painless decrease in vision caused by lens opacity, may be accompanied by glare, poor night vision, and refractive changes. Diagnosis can be confirmed by slit-lamp examination.
Age-Related Macular Degeneration
A degenerative disease affecting the macular area, presenting with decreased central vision and metamorphopsia. OCT/fluorescein angiography may reveal neovascularization or leakage.
Hordeolum
Acute purulent inflammation of the eyelid margin, often seen as a localized small nodule with redness, swelling, and pain, which may develop a pustule.
Diabetic Retinopathy (Mild)
Retinal microvascular disease caused by glucose metabolism disorder. Fundoscopy reveals microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates. Macular edema can lead to decreased vision.
Herpes Simplex Keratitis
Caused by herpes virus infection of the cornea, characterized by dendritic ulcers upon fluorescein staining, accompanied by eye pain, photophobia, and lacrimation.
Meibomian Gland Dysfunction

Dry eye symptoms caused by abnormal secretion of the meibomian glands, presenting with eye discomfort, a burning sensation, and fluctuating vision. Examination reveals blocked meibomian gland orifices.
Central Serous Chorioretinopathy
Subretinal fluid accumulation caused by choroidal vascular leakage, presenting with blurred central vision and metamorphopsia. OCT reveals fluid accumulation.
Pterygium
A triangular proliferation of conjunctival tissue growing towards the cornea, common with long-term ultraviolet exposure, may cause blurred vision or a sensation of irritation.
Dacryocystitis
Redness, swelling, and pain caused by infection of the lacrimal sac, may be accompanied by purulent discharge, and is often caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
Ptosis
Abnormally low position of the upper eyelid, which may affect the visual field and appearance, common in neurological or muscular diseases.
Entropion
Inward turning of the eyelid margin, where eyelashes may irritate the cornea, leading to discomfort and inflammation.
Ectropion
Outward turning of the eyelid margin, which may lead to poor tear drainage and conjunctival exposure, causing dryness and irritation.
Orbital Cellulitis
Infection of the orbital soft tissues, presenting with eyelid swelling, pain, fever, and decreased vision, possibly accompanied by proptosis.
Myopia
Distant objects are blurry while near objects are clear, caused by an excessively long eyeball or excessive corneal curvature.
Amblyopia
Decreased vision in one or both eyes due to abnormal visual development, typically when not treated in a timely manner during childhood.
Keratoconus
The central part of the cornea bulges outward into a cone shape, which may cause blurred vision and photophobia.
Posterior Vitreous Detachment
Posterior detachment caused by liquefaction and contraction of the vitreous, common in the elderly, may cause symptoms of flashes and floaters.
Chalazion
A painless lump formed by chronic inflammation of a meibomian gland, usually located on the upper or lower eyelid, which may resolve on its own or require surgical removal.
Diabetic Retinopathy (Severe)
Severe retinal disease caused by diabetes, characterized by numerous microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates, which can lead to severe vision loss.
Choroiditis
Inflammation of the choroid, which may be caused by infection, immune reactions, or other diseases, presenting with blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain.
Vitritis
Inflammation within the vitreous cavity, which may be caused by infection, immune reactions, or other diseases, presenting with blurred vision, floaters, and eye pain.
Optic Neuritis
Inflammation of the optic nerve, which may be caused by infection, immune reactions, or other diseases, presenting with decreased vision, abnormal color vision, and eye pain.
